body:
Hi @invino4 - this should do the job:

```
var silent = new LoggerConfiguration().CreateLogger();
```

A little expensive for library code since it requires several allocations.  Something like:

````csharp
    m_logger = (logger ?? Log.NullLogger).ForContext<SomeClass>();
````

where ```Log.NullLogger``` was a static thread-safe singleton would be cheaper.  What do you think?
Still a little awkward, perhaps we should zoom out and look at the scenario in more detail, to see whether there's a better pattern for this?

Makes sense.  The scenario is that I have a number of libraries that are fairly general purpose.  In all of these libraries (and most of my software) mutable global variables are strictly avoided to promote composability, race-free operation, etc.  Strictly speaking, all capabilities are passed down when needed including logging.

Some of the consumers of these libraries are using logging.  If logging is in use, then there is some value in passing a logger to the libraries so they can log their actions (or even do Debug or Verbose/Trace logging).  However, if logging is not in use by the consumer it is onerous to have to pass a logger to the class.  Now the class can easily specify the capability as optional, however, in implementing the class I don't want this flexibility to either complicate the code or negatively impact performance.  The easiest way to prevent this is to ensure that the m_logger field is never-null (and usually readonly).  Now the reasoning about the existence of a logger is confined to the constructor.

Assigning the m_logger to an immutable static implementation (effectively a compile-time constant) is nearly free in most runtime environments (and can be truly zero-cost in the presence of tracing JIT or Whole Program Optimization).  This makes the pattern suitable for both class and struct implementations without having any impact on the allocation profile.  E.g.

````csharp
   for (int i = 0; i < 10000; i++) {
      MyStruct s = new MyStruct(logger: null)
      ...
   }
````

This loop silently, implicitly makes 10000 allocations.  If it is easy, I'd like to avoid this.

> Assigning the m_logger to an immutable static implementation (effectively a compile-time constant) is nearly free in most runtime environments

It should be easy just to create your own `static readonly ILogger NoLogger = new SilentLogger()` to get going, but having a `Logger.None` on the Serilog side does also sound nice. Open to a PR, if anyone is interested in pursuing this further üëç

issue.title: Fixes #1105 - adds static Log.None property with appropriate tests.  ‚Ä¶
issue.body:
**What issue does this PR address?**
Adds a static `Log.None` property as per the discussion in #1105 

**Does this PR introduce a breaking change?**
No

**Please check if the PR fulfills these requirements**
- [X] The commit follows our [guidelines](https://github.com/serilog/serilog/blob/dev/CONTRIBUTING.md)
- [X] Unit Tests for the changes have been added (for bug fixes / features)

**Other information**:
Basic change to stash a `SilentLogger` instance in a private static variable on the `Log` class. That instance is used as the initial value of the `Logger` property.  The same instance is then exposed via the `None` property. `CloseAndFlush()` was modified to reset back to this instance rather than creating yet another `SilentLogger` instance.

Comments were updated where appropriate and code style was preserved.

I've added tests to ensure that the `None` property is initialised properly.  I've also ensured via a test that initialisation of the `Logger` property doesn't affect the `None` property. 
Finally I've ensured that `CloseAndFlush` doesn't corrupt the logger stored and accessible via the `None` property by checking that it remains a `SilentLogger` instance and that we can invoke it without raising an exception.

I think there are lines of words here than lines of code changed in the PR.  All tests (on my machine) seem to pass in the various framework versions.

Thanks üíØ

issue.title: Fixes #1105 - add a static None property to the Logger class
issue.body:
**What issue does this PR address?**
Addresses issue #1105.  Replaces PR #1108 

**Does this PR introduce a breaking change?**
No

**Please check if the PR fulfills these requirements**
- [X] The commit follows our [guidelines](https://github.com/serilog/serilog/blob/dev/CONTRIBUTING.md)
- [X] Unit Tests for the changes have been added (for bug fixes / features)

**Other information**:
Sorry for the new PR.  Given the changes in the old PR were in the completely wrong file, it seemed easier to just close that PR and open a new one.

Issue #1105 asked for an easy way to get at a constant instance of a `SilentLogger`. The original PR added this on the `Log` class and slightly adjusted that class' internals to make use of this instance.
This new PR instead modifies the `Logger` class to add a static `Logger.None` property that returns the same `SilentLogger`.

One new allocation overall.  I suspect we can live with that (?).  Former PR didn't have that issue.  A lazy init sounds like overkill for this but I'm happy to be told I'm wrong.

Only one new unit test - verifying that the property is a silent logger.  There's not a lot of machinery or moving parts to verify anymore compared with the earlier PR.

Feedback most welcome. Thanks üíØ

issue.title: SilentLogger not a singleton, reference comparision with Logger.None
issue.body:
This relates to the Serilog core, this repository

**Does this issue relate to a new *feature* or an existing *bug*?**
It is debatable if this is a new feature or an existing bug. It is also framework independent.

**What version of Serilog is affected?  Please list the related NuGet package.**
Versions from Fixes #1105 up until the current dev as of now https://github.com/serilog/serilog/commit/fcd0c8bb128a853b48869dd7821b3e8661963319

**Please describe the current behavior?**
The SilentLogger instance of Log.Logger is not the same reference as Logger.None, thus it is impossible to determine if Log.Logger has been initialized or not.

**Please describe the expected behavior?**
If Log.Logger has not been initialized, it should be set to the same instance as Logger.None, so Object.ReferenceEquals(Log.Logger, Logger.None) returns a boolean that identifies, whether Log.Logger is uninitialized or closed.

**If the current behavior is a bug, please provide the steps to reproduce the issue and if possible a minimal demo of the problem**
To reproduce, test whether at program start Object.ReferenceEquals(Log.Logger, Logger.None) returns true or false. It should return true until Log.Logger has been assigned a newly created logger. It should also return true when Log.CloseAndFlush() has been called.

My current workaround for this is to initialize Log.Logger = Logger.None at program start and whenever after I used Log.CloseAndFlush()
